title: Modeling Actuations in BCI-O: A Context-based Integration of SOSA and IoT-O

sentences.text: Recent technological developments in Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) will largely enable BCI as a powerful, natural and intuitive mainstream human-computer interaction (HCI) in real-world activities, especially throughout actuators connected to the Internet.
As a type of sensor-actuator system, BCI will integrate novel interfaces that will be fully interoperating with IoT-based systems.

An ontological metadata overlay for BCI systems in real-world applications is defined in the BCI Ontology (BCI-O), which formalizes and integrates BCI-domain-specific Sense and Actuation Models along with a novel Context Model for describing any kind of real/virtual environments.
This paper presents the design principle of BCI-O's Actuation Model, which integrates SOSA and SAN (IoT-O) axioms for actuations and actuators along with the BCI-O's Context Model.

This model will become relevant in the degree as context-based semantic interoperability will become a core pre-requisite for any context-aware BCI actuation application with real-time collaboration in IoT environments.

Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) are systems that determine a user's brain states by collecting and analyzing her neurophysiological signals (which are highly situational, individual dependent, and non-stationary in characteristics) and then actuating specific responses, for example to drive her wheelchair autonomously.

Key developments in wearable sensors, wireless networks, and distributed computing will largely enable BCI as a powerful, natural and intuitive mainstream human-computer interaction (HCI) in real-world activities.
In a not too far future, BCI will be regarded as the ultimate HCI system, integrating novel interfaces that will be fully interoperating with Internet-of-Things- (IoT)-based systems.
In this scenario, context-based semantic interoperability will be a core pre-requisite for any context-aware BCI application with real-time collaboration in IoT environments.

The BCI Ontology (BCI-O) [1] is the first OWL 2 ontology that formalizes relevant metadata for BCI data capture activities by integrating BCI-domain-specific Sense and Actuation Models along with a novel Context Model for describing any kind of real/virtual environments.

Due that BCI is a type of sensor-actuator system, as an ontological metadata overlay for BCI systems in real-world applications, BCI-O is properly aligned with the W3C Semantic Sensor Network (SSN) and Sensor, Observation, Sample, and Actuator (SOSA) [2] upper ontologies.

Because many BCI devices, especially actuators, are connected to the Internet, BCI-O is also aligned with the core actuation semantic model for the IoT ontology (IoT-O) [3]: the Semantic Actuator Network (SAN) [5].
BCI-O makes an important contribution: the introduction of the concepts of context and contextual relations [1].

This puts the architectural description of any context as a first-class semantic model that enables BCI applications to be context-aware, laying the foundations of meaningful interactions with IoT-based systems.
This paper presents the structure and design principle of BCI-O's Actuation Model, which integrates SOSA and SAN (IoT-O) axioms for actuations and actuators along with the BCI-O's Context Model.
A use case for this model is explained in a subsequent section.
Lastly, the main contribution is summarized in the conclusions.
BCI-O origins, purpose, core models, global overview, public access (spec and examples), design principles, and applications are described in [1].

At its core, BCI-O defines the conceptual components in any BCI through a bidirectional subject-context interaction model (a BCI session with sensors/actuators): a Sense Model (context to subject) and an Actuation Model (subject to context), as depicted in Fig. 1.
Its Actuation Model is based on the
Two distinct conceptual domains are found in this interaction model: BCI domain (observations, actuations, and interactions) and context domain (surroundings).
Following, a brief description of BCI-O's core modules related to actuations are presented:
Session: represents the interaction between a bci:Subject and a bci:Context while performing (bci:Session) a single bci:Activity.
A bci:Session groups both observations (multimodal records: bci:Record) and actuations (bci:Actuation).
Context: captures the architectural description of any physical/virtual environment.
Its conceptual components enable the structural, functional, and temporal complexity definitions of any environment (Fig. 4).

Under the bci:Context.Event classification, BCI-O defines three key concepts that bind the contextual integration (including with its Actuation Model): bci:StimulusEvent (a stimulus to the bci:Subject), bci:Action (issued by a bci:Subject while performing a bci:Activity), and bci:ActuationEvent (an effect -change of state- in bci:Context as the result of bci:Actuation).
Observations: describes the contextual input data and events to the subject [3].
Specific concepts aligned to the SOSA/SSN axioms [2] are defined for modeling observations.

These are related to bci:Record (a single observation, and input to an actuator), bci:Modality types, aspects (bci:Aspect), channeling specs (bci:ChannelingSpec), sensor output (bci:RecordedData), and bci:StimulusEvent.
Actuation: integrated concepts aligned to the SOSA and SAN (IoT-O) axioms for modeling actuations and actuators.
This model depicts how the bci:Subject can interact with the bci:Context [3].
This model was developed based on the following premises:
Aims to integrate and reconcile SOSA and SAN axioms for modeling actuations and actuators (Fig. 2 and Fig. 3).
Follows closely the proposed Actuation-Actuator-Effect (AAE) ontology design pattern [4]: a core model for the IoT Ontology (IoT-O)1 [3] (Fig. 3).
3.1 Core Abstractions
Actuation: Carries out a procedure to change the state of the context using an actuator.
The relationships from and to actuation and other concepts are the ones defined at [2].
bci:Actuation is aligned to both sosa:Actuation and san:Actuation.

Actuation Event: Represents a transition (something that has changed from a state to a different one: actuation target) ─ a modification (impacted property, as a consequence of an actuation effect) ─ in the context as the result of an actuation (actuation result involves actuation event).
From the context perspective, this concept is a context event (triggered by an actuator) that changes the impacted property of the actuation target.
bci:ActuationEvent is aligned to both bci:Context.Event and san:Effect.
Following the AAE ODP [4], this concept is taken from the following relationships involving the san:Effect definition [5]:
san:Actuator - (triggers) -> san:Effect
san:Actuation - (involves) -> san:Effect
san:Effect - (impacts) -> bci:ImpactedProperty
Actuation Result: It represents the result of an actuation [2], i.e. an entity representing the “effect” of the actuation, which involves an actuation event.
bci:ActuationResult is aligned to both sosa:Result and san:ActuationValue.
Following the AAE ODP [4], this concept expands the following relationship:
san:Actuation - (involves) -> san:Effect
Actuation Target: Its modeling depiction is based on the composition of three concepts.
The first, as a sosa:FeatureOfInterest [2]: the thing (actuation target) whose property (impacted property) is being manipulated by an actuator.

The second, related from a sosa:Actuation via the property sosa:hasFeatureOfInterest [2]: a relation between an actuation and the entity (actuation target) whose property (an impacted property as a consequence of an actuation effect) was modified.
And the third one, a bci:Context.Object: a thing (object) in the contextual interaction of the bci:Session.
bci:ActuationTarget is aligned to both bci:Context.Object and sosa:FeatureOfInterest.
Following the AAE ODP [4], this concept captures the definition of sosa:FeatureOfInterest from the following relation:
bci:ImpactedProperty - (is property of) -> sosa:FeatureOfInterest
Actuator: A device that is used by, or implements, an actuation that changes the state of the context.
According to [3], actuators are devices that transform an input signal into a physical output, making them the exact opposite of sensors.
bci:Actuator is aligned to both sosa:Actuator and san:Actuator.
Command: Represents a specific order (based on a bci:Record) to an actuator to perform an actuation.
Typically, it depicts an instruction (or signal) that causes an actuator to perform (executes) one of its basic functions, and thus, triggering an actuation.
A command defines the input for a set of actuators from a specific source: a set of bci:Record.
bci:Command is aligned to both dul:Method and san:ActuatorInput.
Following the AAE ODP [4], this concept is based on the following definition:
[AAE::Actuator] - (AAE::consumes) -> [AAE::Input]
bci:Actuator - (bci:executes) -> bci:Command
Impacted Property: Represents an actuatable quality (property or characteristic) of an actuation target.

An actuator connects to an impacted property (as a consequence of an actuation effect) via the object property ssn:forProperty [2], i.e., an actuator triggers an actuation event that causes an effect (modification) on the actuation target: impacted property [4].
bci:ImpactedProperty is aligned to sosa:ActuatableProperty.
Following the AAE ODP [4], this concept captures the definition of Impacted Property (linked to san:Effect) from the following relationships:
san:Effect - (impacts) -> bci:ImpactedProperty
bci:ImpactedProperty - (is property of) -> sosa:FeatureOfInterest
3.2 Modeling Integration: BCI-O Context Model with SOSA and SAN Alignments
As a broad application domain ontology for BCI activities, BCI-O integrates and refines some modeling considerations of the SOSA and SAN concepts regarding actuations and actuators.
The “context-aware” domain level concepts were aligned initially to SOSA/SSN.
Afterwards, they were integrated with proper alignments to SAN (IoT-O), following closely their axiomatization satisfiability.
The main modeling integration was done with the actuation event alignment to san:Effect (or san:ActuatorOutput).
san:Effect is defined in [5] as “concept bound to the definition of an actuator as an agent having an effect on the physical world.
Therefore, an effect is any kind of physical modification induced by an actuator”.

In order to be more semantically precise, and based on the SOSA/SSN definitions aligned with Dolce-Ultralite (DUL) in [2] (Vertical Segmentation: DUL alignment module), the concept san:Effect is described distinctively by the following combined ontological notions along with BCI-O's Context Model:

A happening that impacts a quality (dul:Quality), or property (ssn:Property), with the capability of an actuation to act on it (sosa:actsOnProperty), that is, a type of sosa:ActuatableProperty, i.e. the bci:ImpactedProperty.
An event (dul:Event) triggered by an actuator, that modifies (changes) the physical world (actuation target): a type of bci:Context.Event; the actuation event.

(An effect is seeing as...) Any kind (of an impacted property) of physical modification (an effect on the physical world — context) as the result of an actuation (an actuation result involves an actuation event), induced by an actuator (a characteristic of its nature, as an agent that has an effect on the context).
An actuation event is a bci:Context.Event triggered by an actuator that changes the state of the actuation target (which is a bci:Context.Object) (see Fig. 4).
Another inherited modeling perspective for BCI, comes from the definition of san:impacts object property: san:Effect - ( san:impacts ) -> oldssn:Property.
Also, BCI-O's alignment to SAN allows the following inferred relationship:
bci:ActuationEvent - (·san:impacts·) -> bci:ImpactedProperty

Last, in order to be consistent in the BCI-O's overall structure and intention, direct alignments to DUL were considered carefully evaluating the scope and constraints for each concept, which led to properly define class hierarchies and disjoint axioms, especially for its Actuation Model.
The following use case depicts how to define related BCI-O actuation concepts (its description and source code is available online in the spec's human-readable version [1]).
Its purpose is to use an actuator capable to control a wheelchair based on the input from a BCI/EEG record (obtained directly from the subject's head).

In this use case, Alice is driving a wheelchair throughout a human interface composed of three major components: (1) an EEG sensor capable of reading brain signals, (2) a computing system capable to process and analyze (classify) the brain signals collected from the EEG sensor, and (3) an actuator capable to control the wheelchair's movement (such as direction and acceleration) based on the input from the EEG recordings.

The actuator is a device that implements the procedure (actuation) to control the wheelchair, which triggers a series of steps aimed to change the wheelchair's state, such as to decelerate its wheels.
The input to the actuator are the observed and processed brain signals that issue specific movement commands.
For example, the “slow down” command with the parameters (and values) of “direction” (“go forward” -no change in the direction-) and “acceleration” (-10.5 cm/s² -change in the speed-).
The modeled concepts involved in this scenario (see Fig.5), excluding those from the observation component (except EEG-Record and EEG-Device), are listed below:
bci:Subject (1 individual = x1): “Alice”.
bci:Session (x1): “a situation where the EEG recording and actuation happened”.
bci:Activity (x1): “controlling the automated wheelchair”.
bci:Context (x1): “at home”.
bci:Context.Scene (x1): “specific indoors situation”.
bci:EegRecord (x1): “EEG observation that serves as the input of the actuations”.
bci:EegDevice (x1): “EEG device that made the EEG recordings”.
bci:Command (x1): “slow down”, actuators' input from the EEG record.
bci:Actuator (2 individuals = x2): “the devices that perform the actuations”.
bci:Actuation (x2): “procedures that change the state of the wheels via actuators”.
bci:ImpactedProperty (x2): “the speed of the wheels (their state)”.
bci:ActuationEvent (x2): “reduce the speed of wheels”.
bci:ActuationResult (x2): “slowing down” (“effect of decelerating the wheels”).
bci:ActuationTarget (x2): “two rear wheels”.
bci:Context.Object (composite) (x1): “wheelchair”.
bci:Context.Method (x1): “deceleration of a wheel”.

BCI-O's Actuation Model provides a mechanism to correlate the observed/analyzed raw data [1], with the contextual components that the subject interacts with, through actuators (IoT devices), identifying how the actuations affect the context.
This is useful in BCI context-aware applications to model how subjects use actuators and interact with the environment, for “intelligent” subject-context personalization.
BCI-O's Actuation Model integrates carefully both standard axiomatization models for actuations, developed by W3C/OGC [2] and IoT [3] [5] communities, based on its Context Model.
Thus, its structure follows closely the AAE ODP [4], while aligning to SOSA/SSN and SAN (IoT-O) concepts, based on contextual notions.

The SOSA-SAN integrated Actuation Model of BCI-O represents a major contribution to the IoT and BCI communities, especially because its structure includes contextual notions that enables its usage in context-aware BCI-IoT integrated applications.
Semantically-enabled BCIs will play a key role in the future “Internet of Brains” interoperating completely with IoT [6].

Under this vision, where one could semantically model, interoperate and control real life objects throughout BCIs connected to the Internet, BCI-O's Actuation Model would become a core semantic structure that integrates BCI, IoT, and contextual concepts in real-world scenarios.

It is important noting that as part of the BCI-O's Actuation Model development, the author raised the issue to the W3C Spatial Data on the Web Working Group [7], regarding the mapping of SOSA/SSN to AAE ODP, due of their structural resemblance.

Entity-bci_ontology.label: BCI Ontology
Entity-bci_ontology.description: The BCI Ontology (BCI-O) is an ontological metadata framework that formalizes and integrates Sense and Actuation Models specific to Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems, along with a Context Model for describing real and virtual environments.

Entity-bci-o_context_model.label: BCI-O Context Model
Entity-bci-o_context_model.description: The BCI-O Context Model is an ontological framework designed to describe and integrate context-aware concepts for Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) systems, facilitating semantic interoperability with Internet of Things (IoT) applications by aligning with the Sensor, Observation, Sample, and Actuator (SOSA) and Semantic Sensor Network (SAN) ontologies.

Entity-bci-o_s_actuation_model.label: BCI-O's Actuation Model
Entity-bci-o_s_actuation_model.description: BCI-O's Actuation Model is a core semantic structure that integrates Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) and Internet of Things (IoT) concepts with contextual elements, enabling context-aware actuation in real-world applications.

Entity-bci-domain-specific_sense_and_act.label: BCI-domain-specific Sense and Actuation Models
Entity-bci-domain-specific_sense_and_act.description: BCI-domain-specific Sense and Actuation Models are formalized frameworks within the BCI Ontology that integrate sensor and actuator functionalities tailored for Brain-Computer Interface applications, enabling context-aware interactions in real and virtual environments.

Entity-bci_actuation_application.label: BCI actuation application
Entity-bci_actuation_application.description: The BCI actuation application refers to a context-aware system that utilizes Brain-Computer Interface technology to enable real-time collaboration and interaction with actuators in Internet of Things environments, leveraging semantic interoperability for effective human-computer interaction.

Entity-sosa-san_integrated_actuation_mod.label: SOSA-SAN integrated Actuation Model
aliases: SOSA-SAN integrated Actuation Model of BCI-O
Entity-sosa-san_integrated_actuation_mod.description: The SOSA-SAN integrated Actuation Model is a framework within the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) that combines the SOSA and SAN axioms to facilitate context-aware actuation in Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) and Internet of Things (IoT) applications.

mentions.local_name: SOSA-SAN integrated Actuation Model of BCI-O

Entity-sense_and_actuation_model.label: Sense and Actuation Models
Entity-sense_and_actuation_model.description: Sense and Actuation Models refer to the formalized frameworks within the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) that integrate domain-specific models for describing the interactions and functionalities of actuators in Brain-Computer Interface systems, particularly in the context of real-world applications and IoT environments.

Entity-modeling_actuation_and_actuator.label: modeling actuations and actuators
Entity-modeling_actuation_and_actuator.description: Modeling actuations and actuators refers to the integration of concepts aligned with the SOSA and SAN (IoT-O) axioms to define how a subject in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) interacts with its context through actuations, facilitating the understanding and implementation of sensor-actuator systems in real-world applications.

Entity-the_ultimate_hci_system.label: the ultimate HCI system
Entity-the_ultimate_hci_system.description: The ultimate HCI system refers to an advanced Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) that seamlessly integrates with Internet-of-Things (IoT) systems, enabling intuitive and context-aware human-computer interactions through the analysis of neurophysiological signals and the actuation of responses.

Entity-design_principle_of_bci-o_s_actua.label: design principle of BCI-O's Actuation Model
aliases: the design principle of BCI-O's Actuation Model
design principle of BCI-O's Actuation Model
Entity-design_principle_of_bci-o_s_actua.description: The design principle of BCI-O's Actuation Model refers to the foundational guidelines that govern the integration of SOSA and SAN axioms for actuations and actuators within the BCI Ontology, aimed at enhancing context-based semantic interoperability in Brain-Computer Interface applications.

mentions.local_name: design principle of BCI-O's Actuation Model
the design principle of BCI-O's Actuation Model

Entity-bci-o_s_alignment_to_san.label: BCI-O's alignment to SAN
Entity-bci-o_s_alignment_to_san.description: BCI-O's alignment to SAN refers to the integration of the BCI Ontology's Actuation Model with the Semantic Sensor Network (SAN) framework, facilitating semantic interoperability between BCI systems and IoT environments by aligning concepts related to actuations and their effects.

Entity-context-based_semantic_interopera.label: context-based semantic interoperability
Entity-context-based_semantic_interopera.description: Context-based semantic interoperability refers to the ability of Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) systems to effectively communicate and operate within Internet of Things (IoT) environments by utilizing contextual information to enhance real-time collaboration and actuation applications.

Entity-actuation_model.label: Actuation Model
Entity-actuation_model.description: The Actuation Model is a conceptual framework within the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) that defines how a subject interacts with a context through actuations, integrating principles from the SOSA and IoT-O axioms to facilitate context-aware interactions in Brain-Computer Interface applications.

Entity-semantically-enabled_bcis.label: Semantically-enabled BCIs
Entity-semantically-enabled_bcis.description: Semantically-enabled BCIs refer to advanced brain-computer interfaces that utilize semantic technologies to facilitate interoperability and context-aware interactions with Internet of Things (IoT) systems, thereby enhancing human-computer interaction in real-world applications.

Entity-bci-o_actuation_concept.label: BCI-O actuation concepts
Entity-bci-o_actuation_concept.description: BCI-O actuation concepts refer to the defined principles and models within the BCI Ontology that describe how actuators, driven by brain-computer interface inputs, interact with and affect real-world environments, particularly in applications like controlling a wheelchair based on EEG signals.

Entity-context-aware_bci-iot_integrated_.label: context-aware BCI-IoT integrated applications
Entity-context-aware_bci-iot_integrated_.description: Context-aware BCI-IoT integrated applications refer to software solutions that leverage Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) technology and Internet of Things (IoT) systems, enabling real-time interaction and control of devices based on contextual information.

Entity-sosa_and_san__iot-o__axiom.label: SOSA and SAN (IoT-O) axioms
Entity-sosa_and_san__iot-o__axiom.description: The SOSA and SAN (IoT-O) axioms are foundational principles used in the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) to define and facilitate the integration of actuations and actuators within the context of Internet of Things (IoT) systems, enhancing semantic interoperability in Brain-Computer Interface applications.

Entity-application.label: applications
Entity-application.description: In the context of the BCI-O framework, 'applications' refer to the various use cases and implementations of the BCI Ontology that facilitate context-aware actuation in Brain-Computer Interface systems integrated with Internet of Things environments.

Entity-system.label: systems
Entity-system.description: In the context of this paper, 'systems' refers to Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) that analyze neurophysiological signals to determine a user's brain states and actuate responses, enabling intuitive human-computer interaction and integration with Internet-of-Things (IoT) environments.

Entity-bci_activity.label: BCI activities
Entity-bci_activity.description: BCI activities refer to the broad application domain of Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) systems, encompassing the integration and modeling of actuations and actuators within the context of human-computer interaction and Internet of Things (IoT) environments.

Entity-actuation.label: actuations
Entity-actuation.description: In the context of Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI), 'actuations' refer to the processes or actions facilitated by actuators that are integrated within the BCI-O's Actuation Model, which aims to enable context-aware interactions in IoT environments.

Entity-contextual_relation.label: contextual relations
aliases: the concepts of context and contextual relations
Entity-contextual_relation.description: The term 'contextual relations' refers to the concepts introduced in the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) that define the relationships and interactions between various contexts in which Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) applications operate, enabling context-aware functionalities in IoT environments.

mentions.local_name: the concepts of context and contextual relations

Entity-ontological_metadata_overlay.label: ontological metadata overlay
Entity-ontological_metadata_overlay.description: The ontological metadata overlay is a framework defined in the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) that formalizes and integrates domain-specific Sense and Actuation Models along with a Context Model to enhance the interoperability and contextual understanding of Brain-Computer Interface systems in real-world applications.

Entity-bci_data_capture_activity.label: BCI data capture activities
Entity-bci_data_capture_activity.description: BCI data capture activities refer to the processes involved in collecting and analyzing neurophysiological signals from users in Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) systems, which are formalized through the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) to enable context-aware interactions in real and virtual environments.

Entity-sensorsactuators.label: sensors/actuators
Entity-sensorsactuators.description: In the context of Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI), 'sensors/actuators' refer to the integrated devices that facilitate bidirectional interaction between the user and their environment, enabling the collection of contextual data (sensors) and the execution of actions or responses (actuators) within a BCI session.

Entity-real-world_application.label: real-world applications
Entity-real-world_application.description: The term 'real-world applications' refers to practical implementations of Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) systems that utilize an ontological metadata overlay to enhance interoperability and functionality in various real and virtual environments.

Entity-san.label: SAN
Entity-san.description: SAN refers to a set of axioms from the IoT-O ontology that are integrated into the BCI-O's Actuation Model to facilitate the interoperability of actuations and actuators in Brain-Computer Interface systems.

Entity-sense_model.label: Sense Model
Entity-sense_model.description: The Sense Model is a conceptual component within the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) that describes the interaction from the context to the subject in a bidirectional subject-context interaction model used in Brain-Computer Interfaces.

Entity-iot-o.label: IoT-O
Entity-iot-o.description: IoT-O refers to a set of axioms that are integrated into the BCI-O's Actuation Model, facilitating the interoperability of Brain-Computer Interface systems with Internet of Things environments.

Entity-semantic_actuator_network.label: Semantic Actuator Network
Entity-semantic_actuator_network.description: The Semantic Actuator Network (SAN) is a core actuation semantic model within the Internet of Things ontology (IoT-O) that facilitates the integration and interoperability of actuators in Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) systems connected to the Internet.

Entity-sosa_and_san_axiom.label: SOSA and SAN axioms
Entity-sosa_and_san_axiom.description: The SOSA and SAN axioms refer to foundational ontological frameworks used for modeling actuations and actuators within the context of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O), facilitating semantic interoperability in Brain-Computer Interface applications.

Entity-relation.label: relation
Entity-relation.description: In the context of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O), 'relation' refers to the semantic connections and interactions between various concepts such as actuation, actuators, and their effects within the framework of modeling actuations and actuators in Brain-Computer Interface systems.

Entity-a_use_case_for_this_model.label: A use case for this model
aliases: A use case for this model
Entity-a_use_case_for_this_model.description: A use case for this model refers to a specific application scenario that demonstrates the practical implementation and effectiveness of the BCI Ontology's Actuation Model in facilitating context-aware interactions within Brain-Computer Interface systems integrated with Internet of Things technologies.

mentions.local_name: A use case for this model

Entity-bci_context-aware_application.label: BCI context-aware applications
Entity-bci_context-aware_application.description: BCI context-aware applications are software systems that utilize brain-computer interface technology to adapt and respond to the user's context and interactions with their environment.

Entity-brain-computer_interface.label: Brain-Computer Interfaces
Entity-brain-computer_interface.description: Brain-Computer Interfaces are systems that facilitate direct communication between the brain and external devices, enabling users to control technology through neural activity.

Entity-the_main_contribution.label: the main contribution
Entity-the_main_contribution.description: The main contribution refers to the introduction of the concepts of context and contextual relations in the BCI Ontology (BCI-O), which establishes a first-class semantic model for context-aware BCI applications that interact meaningfully with IoT-based systems.

Entity-bci_system.label: BCI systems
Entity-bci_system.description: BCI systems, or Brain-Computer Interface systems, are technologies that enable direct communication between the brain and external devices, allowing for control and interaction without the need for traditional input methods.

Entity-context.label: context
Entity-context.description: The term 'context' refers to a novel Context Model within the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) that is designed to describe various real and virtual environments, facilitating context-aware interactions in Brain-Computer Interface applications.

Entity-modeling_integration.label: modeling integration
Entity-modeling_integration.description: Modeling integration refers to the process of aligning and reconciling the BCI-O Context Model with the SOSA and SAN ontologies to enhance the semantic interoperability of actuations and actuators in Brain-Computer Interface applications.

Entity-meaningful_interaction.label: meaningful interactions
Entity-meaningful_interaction.description: Meaningful interactions refer to the context-aware exchanges and engagements facilitated by Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) applications that integrate with Internet-of-Things (IoT) systems, allowing for intuitive and effective communication and control in real-world environments.

Entity-bci_application.label: BCI application
Entity-bci_application.description: A BCI application refers to a software or system that utilizes brain-computer interface technology to facilitate communication or control between the human brain and external devices.

Entity-novel_interface.label: novel interfaces
Entity-novel_interface.description: Novel interfaces refer to innovative interaction mechanisms within Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) that enable seamless integration and interoperability with Internet of Things (IoT) systems, enhancing human-computer interaction in real-world applications.

Entity-bidirectional_subject-context_int.label: bidirectional subject-context interaction model
Entity-bidirectional_subject-context_int.description: The bidirectional subject-context interaction model is a theoretical framework within the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) that describes the interaction between a subject and its context during a BCI session, comprising a Sense Model that captures context-to-subject information and an Actuation Model that facilitates subject-to-context actions.

Entity-bci__context.event.label: bci:Context.Event
Entity-bci__context.event.description: bci:Context.Event refers to a classification within the BCI Ontology that encompasses key concepts related to the integration of context and actuation in Brain-Computer Interface systems, specifically including bci:StimulusEvent, bci:Action, and bci:ActuationEvent.

Entity-observation__actuation__and_inter.label: observations, actuations, and interactions
Entity-observation__actuation__and_inter.description: The term 'observations, actuations, and interactions' refers to the core components of the BCI domain within the BCI Ontology (BCI-O), which encompasses the multimodal input data (observations), the actions taken by the subject (actuations), and the dynamic exchanges between the subject and their context (interactions) during Brain-Computer Interface sessions.

Entity-context_and_contextual_relation.label: context and contextual relations
Entity-context_and_contextual_relation.description: The term 'context and contextual relations' refers to the foundational concepts introduced in the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) that enable the architectural description of any context as a first-class semantic model, facilitating context-aware interactions in Brain-Computer Interface applications integrated with Internet-of-Things systems.

Entity-contextual_concept.label: contextual concepts
Entity-contextual_concept.description: The term 'contextual concepts' refers to the theoretical and practical ideas that underpin the integration of context-aware elements within the BCI-O's Actuation Model, facilitating interoperability between Brain-Computer Interfaces and Internet of Things systems in real-world applications.

Entity-specific_concept_aligned_to_the_s.label: Specific concepts aligned to the SOSA/SSN axioms
aliases: Specific concepts aligned to the SOSA/SSN axioms
Entity-specific_concept_aligned_to_the_s.description: Specific concepts aligned to the SOSA/SSN axioms refer to the defined elements and structures used in the BCI Ontology for accurately modeling observations within the context of Brain-Computer Interaction, ensuring semantic interoperability with sensor-actuator systems.

mentions.local_name: Specific concepts aligned to the SOSA/SSN axioms

Entity-bci_device.label: BCI devices
Entity-bci_device.description: BCI devices are technological systems that facilitate direct communication between the brain and external devices, enabling users to control them through neural activity.

Entity-real-world_activity.label: real-world activities
Entity-real-world_activity.description: Real-world activities refer to practical, everyday tasks and interactions that individuals engage in, which can be enhanced or facilitated by Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) technologies and their integration with Internet of Things (IoT) systems.

Entity-integrated_concept.label: integrated concepts
Entity-integrated_concept.description: Integrated concepts refer to the structured and formalized elements within the BCI-O Actuation Model that align with the SOSA and SAN (IoT-O) axioms, facilitating the modeling of interactions between subjects and contexts in Brain-Computer Interface systems.

Entity-bci__activity.label: bci:Activity
Entity-bci__activity.description: bci:Activity refers to a specific task or action performed by a bci:Subject within the context of a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) session, which is integral to the interaction model that connects observations and actuations in real or virtual environments.

Entity-core_model.label: core models
Entity-core_model.description: The term 'core models' refers to the fundamental conceptual components defined in the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) that facilitate the interaction between subjects and contexts in Brain-Computer Interface systems, specifically including the Sense Model and Actuation Model.

Entity-san_alignment.label: SAN Alignments
Entity-san_alignment.description: SAN Alignments refer to the integration and reconciliation of SAN axioms within the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) framework, specifically for modeling actuations and actuators in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction and Internet of Things applications.

Entity-the_relationship_from_and_to_actu.label: The relationships from and to actuation and other concepts
aliases: The relationships from and to actuation and other concepts
Entity-the_relationship_from_and_to_actu.description: The relationships from and to actuation and other concepts refer to the defined connections and interactions between the actuation process and various related concepts within the BCI Ontology, specifically how actuation is integrated with other elements like actuators, effects, and impacted properties in the context of Brain-Computer Interfaces and Internet of Things systems.

mentions.local_name: The relationships from and to actuation and other concepts

Entity-the_context.label: the context
Entity-the_context.description: In this paper, 'the context' refers to the specific environmental and situational factors that influence and are influenced by the interactions between a subject and actuators in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system, as modeled in the BCI Ontology's Actuation Model.

Entity-core_pre-requisite.label: core pre-requisite
Entity-core_pre-requisite.description: A core pre-requisite refers to the essential requirement of context-based semantic interoperability necessary for the effective functioning of context-aware Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) actuation applications within Internet of Things (IoT) environments.

Entity-conceptual_component.label: conceptual components
Entity-conceptual_component.description: The term 'conceptual components' refers to the fundamental elements defined within the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) that facilitate the bidirectional interaction between subjects and contexts in Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) systems, specifically through the Sense Model and Actuation Model.

Entity-context_model.label: Context Model
Entity-context_model.description: The Context Model refers to a novel framework within the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) that is designed to describe and formalize various real and virtual environments in the context of Brain-Computer Interface systems.

Entity-core_module.label: core modules
Entity-core_module.description: The term 'core modules' refers to the fundamental conceptual components of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) that facilitate the interaction between subjects and contexts in Brain-Computer Interface systems, specifically focusing on the Actuation Model and its integration with contextual elements.

Entity-bci__actuation.label: bci:Actuation
Entity-bci__actuation.description: bci:Actuation refers to a formalized concept within the BCI Ontology that represents the process of executing a procedure to change the state of a context using an actuator, and is aligned with the definitions of actuation in both the SOSA and SAN ontologies.

Entity-any_environment.label: any environment
Entity-any_environment.description: The term 'any environment' refers to the conceptual framework within the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) that captures the structural, functional, and temporal complexities of both physical and virtual settings in which Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) interactions occur.

Entity-internet_of_brain.label: Internet of Brains
Entity-internet_of_brain.description: The 'Internet of Brains' refers to a conceptual framework where brain-computer interfaces (BCIs) are fully integrated with the Internet of Things (IoT), enabling semantic interoperability and real-time control of physical objects through brain signals.

Entity-recent_technological_development.label: Recent technological developments
Entity-recent_technological_development.description: Recent technological developments refer to advancements in Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) that enhance their functionality and integration with Internet of Things (IoT) systems, facilitating more intuitive human-computer interactions in real-world applications.

Entity-bci_domain.label: BCI domain
Entity-bci_domain.description: The BCI domain refers to a conceptual area within Brain-Computer Interaction that encompasses observations, actuations, and interactions between a subject and their context.

Entity-bci__context.object.label: bci:Context.Object
Entity-bci__context.object.description: bci:Context.Object refers to an entity that is the target of an actuation within the context of Brain-Computer Interaction, representing a thing whose properties can be manipulated by actuators in a context-aware system.

Entity-bci_community.label: BCI communities
Entity-bci_community.description: BCI communities refer to groups or networks of researchers, developers, and practitioners focused on the development and application of Brain-Computer Interface technologies, particularly in the context of integrating these systems with Internet of Things (IoT) frameworks.

Entity-the_main_modeling_integration.label: The main modeling integration
Entity-the_main_modeling_integration.description: The main modeling integration refers to the alignment of the actuation event within the BCI-O framework to the san:Effect concept, which defines the impact of actuators on the physical world, thereby facilitating semantic interoperability in context-aware Brain-Computer Interface applications.

Entity-bci__subject.label: bci:Subject
Entity-bci__subject.description: The entity 'bci:Subject' refers to a participant in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system that interacts with a contextual environment during a BCI session, performing activities and responding to stimuli.

Entity-bci__context.event_classification.label: bci:Context.Event classification
Entity-bci__context.event_classification.description: The term 'bci:Context.Event classification' refers to a categorization within the BCI Ontology that defines three essential concepts—bci:StimulusEvent, bci:Action, and bci:ActuationEvent—that facilitate the integration of contextual information with the actuation model in Brain-Computer Interface systems.

Entity-bci__modality.label: bci:Modality
Entity-bci__modality.description: bci:Modality refers to the various types of modalities that characterize the different forms of observations and inputs in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system, which are essential for the interaction between the subject and the context.

Entity-san__iot-o_.label: SAN (IoT-O)
Entity-san__iot-o_.description: SAN (IoT-O) refers to a conceptual framework that integrates axioms for actuations and actuators within the context of the Internet of Things, specifically designed to enhance semantic interoperability in Brain-Computer Interface applications.

Entity-contextual_notion.label: contextual notions
Entity-contextual_notion.description: Contextual notions refer to the theoretical concepts that underpin the integration of various models and frameworks in the BCI-O's Actuation Model, facilitating context-aware applications in Brain-Computer Interaction and the Internet of Things.

Entity-the_environment.label: the environment
Entity-the_environment.description: In this context, 'the environment' refers to the real or virtual settings in which subjects interact with actuators in Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) applications, facilitating context-aware personalization and intelligent responses based on user inputs.

Entity-modeled_concept.label: modeled concepts
Entity-modeled_concept.description: The term 'modeled concepts' refers to the specific theoretical and conceptual elements defined within the BCI-O Actuation Model that describe the interactions and relationships between brain-computer interface inputs, actuators, and the contextual environment in which they operate.

Entity-bci__context.scene.label: bci:Context.Scene
Entity-bci__context.scene.description: bci:Context.Scene refers to a specific indoor situation within the context of a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) application, where the interaction between the user and the environment is defined for actuating devices like a wheelchair.

Entity-contextual_component.label: contextual components
Entity-contextual_component.description: The term 'contextual components' refers to the elements within the BCI-O's Actuation Model that represent the various aspects of the environment and situation that a subject interacts with while using actuators in Brain-Computer Interface applications.

Entity-bci__actuator.label: bci:Actuator
Entity-bci__actuator.description: bci:Actuator refers to a device that implements an actuation to change the state of a context, functioning as a component within the BCI Ontology that aligns with the definitions of sosa:Actuator and san:Actuator.

Entity-bci__modality_type.label: bci:Modality types
Entity-bci__modality_type.description: bci:Modality types refers to the classification of different modalities used in Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) systems, which are essential for modeling observations and inputs to actuators within the BCI-O framework.

Entity-bci__aspect.label: bci:Aspect
Entity-bci__aspect.description: bci:Aspect refers to a conceptual component within the BCI Ontology that categorizes various modalities and characteristics of observations related to brain-computer interaction systems.

Entity-concept.label: concepts
Entity-concept.description: In the context of the BCI-O framework, 'concepts' refers to the specific theoretical constructs and ideas that are aligned with the SOSA/SSN axioms for modeling observations within Brain-Computer Interface systems.

Entity-ontological_notion.label: ontological notions
Entity-ontological_notion.description: Ontological notions refer to the conceptual frameworks and definitions that describe the relationships and properties of entities within a specific domain, particularly in the context of modeling interactions and effects in systems like Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) and the Internet of Things (IoT).

Entity-bci__stimulusevent.label: bci:StimulusEvent
Entity-bci__stimulusevent.description: bci:StimulusEvent refers to a specific type of event in the BCI-O ontology that represents a stimulus directed towards a bci:Subject, facilitating interaction within a context-aware Brain-Computer Interface system.

Entity-another_inherited_modeling_perspe.label: Another inherited modeling perspective for BCI
aliases: Another inherited modeling perspective for BCI
Entity-another_inherited_modeling_perspe.description: Another inherited modeling perspective for BCI refers to the integration of the san:impacts object property within the BCI Ontology, which establishes a relationship between the effects of actuations and the properties they impact, thereby enhancing the semantic modeling of actuation events in Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

mentions.local_name: Another inherited modeling perspective for BCI

Entity-bci__context.label: bci:Context
Entity-bci__context.description: bci:Context refers to the architectural description of any physical or virtual environment within the BCI Ontology, capturing the structural, functional, and temporal complexities that influence the interaction between a BCI subject and their activities.

Entity-sosassn_definition.label: SOSA/SSN definitions
Entity-sosassn_definition.description: The term 'SOSA/SSN definitions' refers to the formalized ontological concepts and axioms from the Sensor, Observation, Sample, and Actuator (SOSA) and Semantic Sensor Network (SSN) ontologies, which are utilized to define and model actuation events, their effects, and the relationships between actuators and the properties they impact within the context of Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) systems.

Entity-san__actuatorinput.label: san:ActuatorInput
Entity-san__actuatorinput.description: san:ActuatorInput refers to a specific type of input signal or command that is utilized by an actuator to perform an actuation in the context of Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) systems.

Entity-the_following_relationship.label: the following relationships
Entity-the_following_relationship.description: The term 'the following relationships' refers to the specific ontological connections and definitions that describe how various concepts such as actuation, actuator, and effect are interrelated within the context of the BCI-O Actuation Model, particularly in relation to the SAN (Semantic Sensor Network) ontology.

Entity-modeling_observation.label: modeling observations
Entity-modeling_observation.description: Modeling observations refers to the process of defining and structuring contextual input data and events related to a subject in Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) systems, utilizing specific concepts aligned with the SOSA/SSN axioms to facilitate the integration of multimodal records and sensor outputs.

Entity-_2_.description: The term '[2]' refers to a specific reference in the context of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) that defines the relationships and alignments between actuation and other related concepts, particularly in relation to the integration of SOSA and SAN axioms.

Entity-bci__context.method.label: bci:Context.Method
Entity-bci__context.method.description: bci:Context.Method refers to the specific actuation procedure of decelerating a wheel in the context of controlling a wheelchair using brain-computer interface (BCI) technology.

Entity-upper_ontology.label: upper ontologies
Entity-upper_ontology.description: Upper ontologies refer to high-level ontological frameworks, such as the W3C Semantic Sensor Network (SSN) and Sensor, Observation, Sample, and Actuator (SOSA), that provide a foundational structure for integrating and standardizing domain-specific ontologies in various applications, including Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) and Internet of Things (IoT) systems.

Entity-state_of_the_context.label: state of the context
Entity-state_of_the_context.description: The 'state of the context' refers to the condition or status of the environment that is modified through the actuation process in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system, facilitated by an actuator.

Entity-module.label: modules
Entity-module.description: In the context of the BCI-O framework, 'modules' refer to the core conceptual components that define the interaction between subjects and contexts in Brain-Computer Interface systems, specifically focusing on aspects related to actuations, sessions, and observations.

Entity-session.label: Session
Entity-session.description: Session refers to the interaction between a BCI subject and context while performing a specific activity, encompassing both observations and actuations within the BCI-O framework.

Entity-interaction.label: interactions
Entity-interaction.description: In the context of the BCI-O framework, 'interactions' refer to the dynamic exchanges between a BCI subject and its surrounding context, encompassing both observations and actuations within a bidirectional interaction model.

Entity-sosa.label: SOSA
Entity-sosa.description: SOSA refers to a modeling framework that provides a set of axioms for integrating actuations and actuators within the context of Brain-Computer Interfaces and the Internet of Things.

Entity-bci__channelingspec.label: bci:ChannelingSpec
Entity-bci__channelingspec.description: bci:ChannelingSpec refers to a specification within the BCI Ontology that defines the parameters and characteristics for channeling data from observations to actuations in Brain-Computer Interface systems.

Entity-purpose.label: purpose
Entity-purpose.description: In the context of the BCI-O framework, 'purpose' refers to the intended function or objective of the BCI-O system, which encompasses its core models and applications designed to facilitate brain-computer interactions.

Entity-subject-context_personalization.label: subject-context personalization
Entity-subject-context_personalization.description: Subject-context personalization refers to the tailored adaptation of Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) applications that enhance user experience by considering the specific context and needs of the individual user, enabling more effective interaction with actuators and the environment.

Entity-a_procedure_to_change_the_state_o.label: a procedure to change the state of the context
aliases: a procedure to change the state of the context
Entity-a_procedure_to_change_the_state_o.description: The term 'a procedure to change the state of the context' refers to the actuation process in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system, where an actuator is employed to modify the properties of a contextual entity, resulting in a transition or event that alters the state of the environment.

mentions.local_name: a procedure to change the state of the context

Entity-core_model_for_the_iot_ontology__.label: core model for the IoT Ontology (IoT-O)
aliases: core model for the IoT Ontology (IoT-O)
Entity-core_model_for_the_iot_ontology__.description: The core model for the IoT Ontology (IoT-O) refers to a foundational framework that integrates and formalizes the relationships and axioms related to actuations and actuators within the Internet of Things, facilitating semantic interoperability and context-aware applications.

mentions.local_name: core model for the IoT Ontology (IoT-O)

Entity-bci__command.label: bci:Command
Entity-bci__command.description: bci:Command refers to a specific order or instruction issued to an actuator within a brain-computer interface system, directing it to perform an actuation based on a bci:Record.

Entity-contextual_input_data_and_event.label: contextual input data and events
aliases: the contextual input data and events to the subject
Entity-contextual_input_data_and_event.description: The term 'contextual input data and events' refers to the multimodal records and stimuli that provide relevant information and interactions from the environment to the subject in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system.

mentions.local_name: the contextual input data and events to the subject

Entity-bci__action.label: bci:Action
Entity-bci__action.description: bci:Action refers to an action issued by a bci:Subject while performing a bci:Activity within the context of the BCI-O framework, which integrates observations and actuations in a bidirectional interaction model.

Entity-bci__actuationtarget.label: bci:ActuationTarget
Entity-bci__actuationtarget.description: bci:ActuationTarget refers to an entity that is the subject of manipulation by an actuator within a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) context, specifically representing the object whose properties are impacted during an actuation event.

Entity-observation_component.label: observation component
Entity-observation_component.description: The observation component refers to the elements in the BCI-O Actuation Model that involve the collection and analysis of brain signals from an EEG sensor, specifically the EEG recordings and the EEG device used to capture these signals, which serve as inputs for actuating commands in a brain-computer interface application.

Entity-actuator_connected_to_the_interne.label: actuators connected to the Internet
Entity-actuator_connected_to_the_interne.description: Actuators connected to the Internet refer to devices that can receive commands and send feedback over the Internet, enabling them to perform actions in response to inputs from Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) and facilitating interaction within Internet of Things (IoT) environments.

Entity-user_s_brain_state.label: user's brain states
Entity-user_s_brain_state.description: The term 'user's brain states' refers to the neurophysiological signals collected and analyzed by Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) to determine the mental and emotional conditions of a user, which are crucial for enabling responsive actions such as autonomous wheelchair driving.

Entity-it_conceptual_component.label: Its conceptual components
Entity-it_conceptual_component.description: The term 'Its conceptual components' refers to the elements within the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) that define the structural, functional, and temporal complexities of any physical or virtual environment in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction.

Entity-context_domain.label: context domain
Entity-context_domain.description: The 'context domain' refers to the conceptual area within the BCI-O framework that encompasses the surroundings and environmental factors relevant to the interactions between a BCI subject and the system.

Entity-contextual_input_data.label: contextual input data
Entity-contextual_input_data.description: The term 'contextual input data' refers to the observations and events that provide relevant information about the environment and stimuli to the subject in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system.

Entity-domain_level_concept.label: domain level concepts
Entity-domain_level_concept.description: Domain level concepts refer to the high-level theoretical constructs that are integrated and aligned with the SOSA and SAN frameworks to model context-aware interactions in Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) systems.

Entity-iot_and_bci_community.label: IoT and BCI communities
Entity-iot_and_bci_community.description: The IoT and BCI communities refer to the collective groups of researchers, developers, and practitioners focused on the Internet of Things (IoT) and Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) technologies, which explore the integration and application of these fields.

Entity-instruction.label: instruction
Entity-instruction.description: In the context of Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI), 'instruction' refers to a specific command or signal that directs an actuator to execute a function, thereby initiating an actuation process.

Entity-actuationresult.label: ActuationResult
Entity-actuationresult.description: ActuationResult refers to the outcome of the actuation process in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system, specifically indicating the effect of decelerating the wheelchair's wheels as a response to processed brain signal commands.

Entity-observed_and_processed_brain_sign.label: observed and processed brain signals
Entity-observed_and_processed_brain_sign.description: Observed and processed brain signals refer to the EEG-derived data that has been analyzed to generate specific movement commands for actuators in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system, enabling control of devices such as wheelchairs based on the user's neural activity.

Entity-procedure.label: procedure
Entity-procedure.description: The term 'procedure' refers to a systematic method or process employed to change the state of a context through the use of an actuator in the context of Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) systems.

Entity-bci__recordeddata.label: bci:RecordedData
Entity-bci__recordeddata.description: bci:RecordedData refers to the sensor output data that serves as a single observation input to an actuator within the context of Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) systems.

Entity-bci__session.label: bci:Session
Entity-bci__session.description: bci:Session refers to a specific situation in which EEG recording and actuation occur, facilitating the interaction between brain signals and actuator responses in a BCI context.

Entity-physicalvirtual_environment.label: physical/virtual environment
Entity-physicalvirtual_environment.description: The term 'physical/virtual environment' refers to the architectural framework that encompasses both tangible and digital settings in which interactions occur, specifically within the context of Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) systems.

Entity-an_actuator.label: an actuator
aliases: a device that is used by, or implements, an actuation
Entity-an_actuator.description: An actuator is a device that implements an actuation, transforming an input signal into a physical output to change the state of a context in systems such as Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) and the Internet of Things (IoT).

mentions.local_name: a device that is used by, or implements, an actuation

Entity-dul__method.label: dul:Method
Entity-dul__method.description: dul:Method refers to a conceptual representation of a specific procedure or technique that can be executed by an actuator in the context of Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) systems, particularly in relation to the commands that trigger actuations.

Entity-core_abstraction.label: Core Abstractions
Entity-core_abstraction.description: Core Abstractions refers to a fundamental component of the BCI-O Actuation Model that outlines the procedures and relationships involved in changing the state of a context through actuations and actuators.

Entity-three_concept.label: three concepts
Entity-three_concept.description: The 'three concepts' refer to the foundational elements that compose the Actuation Target in the BCI-O model, specifically including a sosa:FeatureOfInterest, a relationship from an actuation to the entity being manipulated, and a bci:Context.Object representing the object in the contextual interaction.

Entity-dolce-ultralite.label: Dolce-Ultralite
Entity-dolce-ultralite.description: Dolce-Ultralite (DUL) refers to an ontological framework that provides a formal structure for integrating and aligning various concepts related to actuation and context in the domain of Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) and the Internet of Things (IoT).

Entity-event.label: events
Entity-event.description: In the context of the BCI-O framework, 'events' refer to significant occurrences or actions that provide contextual input data to the subject, including stimulus events, actions performed by the subject, and actuation events that result from the subject's interactions with the environment.

Entity-a_series_of_step.label: a series of steps
Entity-a_series_of_step.description: A series of steps refers to the sequential procedures executed by an actuator in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system to effectuate changes in the state of a device, such as controlling the movement of a wheelchair based on processed brain signals.

Entity-sosa__actuation.label: sosa:Actuation
Entity-sosa__actuation.description: sosa:Actuation refers to a conceptual entity within the SOSA ontology that represents the process of carrying out a procedure to change the state of a context using an actuator, integral to the modeling of sensor-actuator systems in contexts such as Brain-Computer Interfaces.

Entity-degree.label: degree
Entity-degree.description: The term 'degree' in this context refers to the level of academic qualification or expertise required for understanding and implementing context-based semantic interoperability in Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) actuation applications.

Entity-modification.label: modification
Entity-modification.description: In the context of Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI), 'modification' refers to the change in the state of an impacted property of an actuation target as a result of an actuation event triggered by an actuator.

Entity-two_distinct_conceptual_domain.label: Two distinct conceptual domains
Entity-two_distinct_conceptual_domain.description: The term 'Two distinct conceptual domains' refers to the BCI domain, which encompasses observations, actuations, and interactions, and the context domain, which pertains to the surrounding environment, as defined within the interaction model of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O).

Entity-alice.label: Alice
Entity-alice.description: Alice is an individual who is using a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) to control a wheelchair through EEG signals in a context-aware application.

Entity-modeling_depiction.label: modeling depiction
Entity-modeling_depiction.description: The term 'modeling depiction' refers to the conceptual representation of the Actuation Target in the BCI-O framework, which is constructed from the integration of three key concepts related to the actuation process.

Entity-scenario.label: scenario
Entity-scenario.description: The term 'scenario' refers to a specific use case in the context of Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) applications, illustrating how various components interact to control a wheelchair based on EEG signals from a subject.

Entity-fig_._1.label: Fig. 1
Entity-fig_._1.description: Fig. 1 is a visual representation that illustrates the conceptual components of a bidirectional subject-context interaction model in brain-computer interfaces (BCIs).

Entity-spec_s_human-readable_version.label: spec's human-readable version
Entity-spec_s_human-readable_version.description: The 'spec's human-readable version' refers to an accessible and comprehensible documentation format of the BCI-O Actuation Model, which includes its description and source code for defining related concepts in Brain-Computer Interface applications.

Entity-capability_of_an_actuation.label: capability of an actuation
Entity-capability_of_an_actuation.description: The 'capability of an actuation' refers to the potential of an actuation to influence or modify a specific quality or property of an actuation target, which is represented as a type of actuatable property within the context of Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) systems.

Entity-parameter.label: parameters
Entity-parameter.description: In the context of the BCI-O Actuation Model, 'parameters' refer to specific values associated with commands issued to actuators, such as 'direction' and 'acceleration', which dictate the behavior of devices like a wheelchair based on processed brain signals.

Entity-relationship.label: relationships
Entity-relationship.description: In the context of the BCI-O Actuation Model, 'relationships' refers to the defined connections and associations between actuation and other related concepts, as outlined in the referenced literature.

Entity-specific_response.label: specific responses
Entity-specific_response.description: Specific responses refer to the actions or outputs generated by Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) in reaction to the analysis of a user's neurophysiological signals, such as autonomously driving a wheelchair.

Entity-real_life_object.label: real life objects
Entity-real_life_object.description: Real life objects refer to tangible, physical entities in the real world that can be modeled, controlled, and interacted with through Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCIs) connected to the Internet.

Entity-a_situation_where_the_eeg_recordi.label: a situation where the EEG recording and actuation happened
aliases: a situation where the EEG recording and actuation happened
Entity-a_situation_where_the_eeg_recordi.description: A situation where the EEG recording and actuation happened refers to a specific instance in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) context where brain signals are recorded and subsequently used to control an actuator, such as a wheelchair, based on the processed EEG data.

mentions.local_name: a situation where the EEG recording and actuation happened

Entity-controlling_the_automated_wheelch.label: controlling the automated wheelchair
Entity-controlling_the_automated_wheelch.description: Controlling the automated wheelchair refers to the process of using brain-computer interface (BCI) technology to direct the movement and actions of a wheelchair based on commands derived from the user's brain signals.

Entity-actuation-actuator-effect__aae_.label: Actuation-Actuator-Effect (AAE)
Entity-actuation-actuator-effect__aae_.description: The Actuation-Actuator-Effect (AAE) refers to an ontology design pattern that serves as a foundational model for integrating actuations, actuators, and their effects within the context of the Internet of Things (IoT) ontology, facilitating semantic interoperability in context-aware applications.

Entity-bcieeg.label: BCI/EEG
Entity-bcieeg.description: BCI/EEG refers to technologies that facilitate communication between the brain and external devices, where BCI stands for brain-computer interface and EEG stands for electroencephalography, a method used to record electrical activity of the brain.

Entity-observation.label: observations
Entity-observation.description: In the context of the BCI-O framework, 'observations' refer to the multimodal records that serve as contextual input data and events to the subject, encompassing various concepts such as bci:Record, bci:Modality types, and sensor outputs.

Entity-multimodal_record__bci__record.label: multimodal records: bci:Record
Entity-multimodal_record__bci__record.description: The entity 'multimodal records: bci:Record' refers to a specific type of observation data within the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) that captures contextual input data and events related to a subject's interaction during a BCI session.

Entity-it_basic_function.label: its basic functions
Entity-it_basic_function.description: The term 'its basic functions' refers to the fundamental operations or tasks that an actuator is designed to perform in response to commands, which trigger actuation events in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) context.

Entity-bci__record.label: bci:Record
Entity-bci__record.description: bci:Record refers to a data structure that represents a single observation and serves as an input to an actuator within the context of Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) systems.

Entity-the_following_inferred_relationsh.label: the following inferred relationship
Entity-the_following_inferred_relationsh.description: The following inferred relationship refers to the semantic connection established within the BCI-O framework that links the actuation event to the impacted property, indicating how an actuation event influences or modifies a specific property of the actuation target.

Entity-san__effect_definition.label: san:Effect definition
Entity-san__effect_definition.description: The term 'san:Effect definition' refers to the ontological concept that describes the physical modifications induced by an actuator in the context of Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI), specifically detailing how an actuation event impacts a quality or property of an actuation target.

Entity-a_set_of_bci__record.label: a set of bci:Record
Entity-a_set_of_bci__record.description: A set of bci:Record refers to a collection of structured data entries that serve as input commands for actuators in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system, facilitating the execution of specific actions based on the defined commands.

Entity-this_concept.label: this concept
Entity-this_concept.description: This concept refers to a context event that is triggered by an actuator and results in a change to the impacted property of the actuation target within the framework of the BCI Ontology.

Entity-human_interface.label: human interface
Entity-human_interface.description: The term 'human interface' refers to the integrated system comprising an EEG sensor, a computing system for processing brain signals, and an actuator that collectively enable a user to control a wheelchair through brain-computer interaction.

Entity-axiomatization_model.label: axiomatization models
Entity-axiomatization_model.description: Axiomatization models refer to standardized frameworks developed by W3C/OGC and IoT communities that provide formal structures for defining and integrating actuations within the context of the BCI-O's Actuation Model.

Entity-reduce_the_speed_of_wheel.label: reduce the speed of wheels
Entity-reduce_the_speed_of_wheel.description: The phrase 'reduce the speed of wheels' refers to an actuation event in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system where an actuator decreases the rotational speed of a wheelchair's wheels based on processed brain signals from the user.

Entity-composite.label: composite
Entity-composite.description: In the context of the BCI-O Actuation Model, 'composite' refers to the wheelchair as a complex object that integrates multiple components and functionalities, enabling it to respond to commands derived from brain signals.

Entity-sosa__result.label: sosa:Result
Entity-sosa__result.description: sosa:Result refers to an entity that represents the outcome or effect of an actuation within the context of the BCI-O ontology, specifically aligned with the concept of actuation results in the integration of SOSA and SAN frameworks.

Entity-bci__actuationevent.label: bci:ActuationEvent
Entity-bci__actuationevent.description: bci:ActuationEvent refers to an effect that represents a change of state in the bci:Context resulting from a bci:Actuation within the BCI-O framework.

Entity-bci__executes.label: bci:executes
Entity-bci__executes.description: bci:executes refers to the relationship where a BCI actuator performs a specific command, triggering an actuation process.

Entity-san__actuatoroutput.label: san:ActuatorOutput
Entity-san__actuatoroutput.description: san:ActuatorOutput refers to the concept in the BCI Ontology that represents the output or effect produced by an actuator as a result of an actuation event, which modifies a property of the physical world.

Entity-aae_odp.label: AAE ODP
Entity-aae_odp.description: AAE ODP refers to the Actuation-Actuator-Effect Ontology Design Pattern, which serves as a foundational model for integrating and reconciling actuation concepts within the Internet of Things Ontology (IoT-O) framework.

Entity-actuation_event_alignment.label: actuation event alignment
Entity-actuation_event_alignment.description: Actuation event alignment refers to the integration of the concept of an actuation event, which is a context event triggered by an actuator that modifies the state of an actuation target, with the san:Effect in the BCI-O framework, emphasizing the relationship between actuators and the physical modifications they induce.

Entity-san__effect_-__impact__-__bci__im.label: san:Effect - (impacts) -> bci:ImpactedProperty
Entity-san__effect_-__impact__-__bci__im.description: The entity 'san:Effect - (impacts) -> bci:ImpactedProperty' refers to a relationship in the BCI Ontology that describes how an effect induced by an actuator modifies or influences a specific property of an actuation target within a context-aware system.

Entity-the_following_relationship_(1).label: the following relationship
Entity-the_following_relationship_(1).description: The following relationship refers to the connections and interactions defined in the context of the Actuation-Actuator-Effect (AAE) ontology design pattern, specifically how various concepts such as actuation, effect, and impacted property are interrelated within the BCI-O framework.

Entity-the_procedure__actuation_.label: the procedure (actuation)
Entity-the_procedure__actuation_.description: The procedure (actuation) refers to the series of steps executed by an actuator to change the state of a device, such as controlling the movement of a wheelchair based on processed brain signals in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system.

Entity-specific_indoors_situation.label: specific indoors situation
Entity-specific_indoors_situation.description: The term 'specific indoors situation' refers to a defined context within a home environment where a subject, Alice, interacts with a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system to control a wheelchair, highlighting the unique conditions and parameters of that indoor setting.

Entity-iot_ontology.label: IoT ontology
Entity-iot_ontology.description: The IoT ontology is a formal representation of knowledge that defines the concepts, relationships, and properties relevant to the Internet of Things, facilitating interoperability and data exchange among IoT devices.

Entity-trigger.label: triggers
Entity-trigger.description: In the context of the BCI-O Actuation Model, 'triggers' refers to the relationship where an actuator initiates an effect, resulting in a change in the state of the context.

Entity-san__actuation_-__involves__-__sa.label: san:Actuation - (involves) -> san:Effect
Entity-san__actuation_-__involves__-__sa.description: The relationship 'san:Actuation - (involves) -> san:Effect' refers to the connection where an actuation process leads to a specific effect or change in the state of a context, as defined within the BCI Ontology framework.

Entity-subject_s_head.label: subject's head
Entity-subject_s_head.description: The term 'subject's head' refers to the anatomical location from which brain signals are recorded using an EEG sensor in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system.

Entity-wheel.label: wheels
Entity-wheel.description: In the context of a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system, 'wheels' refers to the mechanical components of a wheelchair that are controlled by an actuator to change the wheelchair's movement state, such as deceleration.

Entity-an_effect_on_the_physical_world.label: an effect on the physical world
aliases: an effect on the physical world
Entity-an_effect_on_the_physical_world.description: An effect on the physical world refers to any physical modification or change in state that results from an actuation event triggered by an actuator within the context of Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) systems.

mentions.local_name: an effect on the physical world

Entity-bci__eegrecord.label: bci:EegRecord
Entity-bci__eegrecord.description: bci:EegRecord refers to the EEG observation data that is utilized as input for actuations in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system, specifically to control devices such as a wheelchair based on brain signals recorded from a subject.

Entity-san__impact.label: san:impacts
Entity-san__impact.description: The entity 'san:impacts' refers to an object property that defines the relationship between an effect produced by an actuator and the property that is impacted as a result of that effect, specifically within the context of the BCI Ontology and its integration with IoT concepts.

Entity-transition.label: transition
Entity-transition.description: In the context of the BCI-O Actuation Model, 'transition' refers to the change from one state to another in an actuation target, characterized as an actuation event that modifies an impacted property as a result of an actuator's effect.

Entity-san__actuator_-__trigger__-__san_.label: san:Actuator - (triggers) -> san:Effect
Entity-san__actuator_-__trigger__-__san_.description: The entity 'san:Actuator - (triggers) -> san:Effect' represents a relationship in the BCI Ontology where an actuator initiates an actuation event that results in a specific effect on the physical world.

Entity-context_event.label: context event
Entity-context_event.description: The term 'context event' refers to an event triggered by an actuator that results in a change to the impacted property of an actuation target within the framework of the BCI Ontology.

Entity-to_decelerate_it_wheel.label: to decelerate its wheels
Entity-to_decelerate_it_wheel.description: The phrase 'to decelerate its wheels' refers to the action performed by an actuator in a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) system that reduces the speed of a wheelchair's wheels based on processed brain signal inputs.

Entity-human-computer_interaction.label: human-computer interaction
Entity-human-computer_interaction.description: Human-computer interaction is a multidisciplinary field of study focused on the design, evaluation, and implementation of interactive computing systems for human use, and the study of the major phenomena surrounding them.

Entity-description.label: description
